claim: Africa is the continent, not the country, with the most poverty.

supporting.text: Africa is a continent, not a country, as defined by standard geographical classifications.

attacks.text: Africa is a continent, not a country, as defined by standard geographical classifications.
While Africa is a continent, some regions within it (e.g., certain African Union member states) exhibit country-like governance structures, blurring the distinction.
Geographical classifications are universally standardized, and political governance does not alter the continental status of Africa.
The term 'country' is sometimes colloquially misapplied to Africa due to generalizations about its economic conditions.
Colloquial misuse does not invalidate formal geographical definitions, which are upheld by academic and international institutions.

supporting.text: Africa has the highest poverty rate among all continents, based on World Bank and UN data.

attacks.text: Africa has the highest poverty rate among all continents, based on World Bank and UN data.
The World Bank and UN data may not account for informal economies and subsistence living, which are prevalent in Africa and may underrepresent actual wealth.
Even if informal economies are considered, the extreme poverty thresholds used by the World Bank still show Africa with the highest rates.
Some regions in Asia, such as South Asia, have comparable or higher poverty rates when adjusted for population density.
Per capita poverty metrics still favor Africa as having the highest concentration of poverty, regardless of population density adjustments.

supporting.text: No single country in Africa has a higher poverty rate than the continent as a whole when measured collectively.

attacks.text: No single country in Africa has a higher poverty rate than the continent as a whole when measured collectively.
Some African countries, like South Sudan, have poverty rates exceeding the continental average when measured individually.
The continental average is skewed by wealthier nations like South Africa and Egypt, masking extreme poverty in specific countries.
Poverty measurement methodologies vary widely across countries, making direct comparisons unreliable.
Standardized metrics like the World Bank's international poverty line allow meaningful cross-country comparisons.

supporting.text: Other continents, such as Asia and South America, have individual countries with high poverty rates, but Africa's aggregate poverty is the highest.

attacks.text: Other continents, such as Asia and South America, have individual countries with high poverty rates, but Africa's aggregate poverty is the highest.
Poverty measurement methodologies vary widely, and aggregate comparisons may not account for differences in cost of living or purchasing power parity.
Standardized metrics like the World Bank's poverty line are adjusted for purchasing power parity, making cross-continental comparisons valid.
Some Asian countries, like India, have larger absolute numbers of people in poverty than any African country, challenging the aggregate claim.
While absolute numbers may be higher in Asia, poverty rates (percentage of population) are consistently higher across African nations.

supporting.text: Poverty metrics, such as the percentage of the population living below the international poverty line, confirm Africa's leading position in global poverty rankings.

attacks.text: Poverty metrics, such as the percentage of the population living below the international poverty line, confirm Africa's leading position in global poverty rankings.
Poverty metrics often rely on arbitrary thresholds like the international poverty line, which may not accurately reflect local living conditions and purchasing power.
The international poverty line is adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP) to account for differences in local costs of living, making it a more reliable metric.
Some regions in Africa, such as North Africa, have significantly lower poverty rates, which are obscured by continent-wide averages.
Even within North Africa, disparities exist, and the overall poverty rate in Africa remains higher than in other continents when weighted by population.
Other continents, like parts of Asia, have comparable or higher poverty rates when considering absolute numbers rather than percentages.
Percentage-based metrics are more meaningful for cross-continental comparisons, as absolute numbers are skewed by population size.
